0.user_question: Fake gold bricks are made by covering concrete cubes with gold paint, so the cost of the paint is proportional to their surface area while the cost of the concrete is proportional to their volume.  If a 1 inch cube costs $\$1.30$ to make while a 2 inch cube costs $\$6.80$, then how much would a 3 inch cube cost?

Since,    $$C(1,\text{inch}) =\$1.3$$      $$\therefore     \$1.3=(k_{p}\cdot 6)+(k_{c}\cdot {1}^{3})$$       i.e.,          $$k_{p}+k_{c}=\frac {\$1.3}6.$$                Equation

Given the cost relationship based on surface area ($1.30$), we confirm this directly matches as one unit of cost covers twelve square inches ($\frac{1.30}{\frac{6}{12}}} = 2$).

For a 2-inch cube, each face doubles in size but still retains circular symmetry – hence doubling every dimension results in quadrupling the surface area due to squared scaling $(\left(2^2\right)^2=2^4=16)$, therefore multiplying the base price accordingly yields double the initial cost, aligning precisely with the provided information indicating such objects require $\$6.80$.
